document.docTitle: Glenognatha vivianae Cabra-García & Brescovit, 2016, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Revision and phylogenetic analysis of the orb-weaving spider genus Glenognatha Simon, 1887 (Araneae, Tetragnathidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision and phylogenetic analysis of the orb-weaving spider genus Glenognatha Simon, 1887 (Araneae, Tetragnathidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Types .
Male
holotype from Barragem do Rio Paraitinga , Salesópolis , São Paulo , Brazil , [ 23º32´5.42´´S , 45º46´56.62´´W ], elev. [
870m
],
11–18.vi.2002
, Eq. IBSP leg., deposited in IBSP 163681
; Paratypes: 13♂ 10♀ from the type locality, 11–18.vi.2002 , Eq. IBSP leg., deposited in IBSP 147861;
1♂ from Reserva Natural da Cachoeira , Antonina , Paraná , Brazil , [ 25º24´2,4´´S , 48º41´18.75´´W ], elev. [
100m
],
28.vi–2.vii.2003
, H
.
Hofer et al. leg., deposited in IBSP
131182
;
1♂ 2♀ from Estaçao Braskem de Proteçao Ambiental , Triunfo ,
Rio Grande
do Sul
, Brazil , [ 29º56´28,27´´S , 51º41´24.41´´W ], elev. [
6m
],
19.xi.2002
, R. Ott leg., deposited in
MCN 34952
;
1♂ 1♀ from
Parque do Estado de São Paulo
, São Paulo ,
São Paulo
, Brazil , [ 23º39´11,45´´S , 46º37´47.15´´W ], elev. [
811m
],
13–20.v.2002
, J. Valvassori leg., deposited in IBSP 59239
.
Etymology. The species epithet is in honor of the first author’s wife, Viviana Motato-Vásquez, in acknowledgment of her constant support and encouragement. The name is a noun in genitive.

Diagnosis. Males of
G. vivianae
can be easily distinguished from all other
Glenognatha
species by the bifurcated embolus tip ( Figs. 82D , 84C ). Females resemble those of
G. australis
by the bean-shaped spermathecae (
Figs. 83 A –D
); distinguished from the latter species by having the Prt1 and Prt 2 subequal in size ( Fig. 81D ).

Male ( holotype )
. Habitus as in
Figures 80 A –D
. Carapace brown, darker along furrows. Sternum brown with darker edges. Abdomen oval, with two irregular dusky bands that join medially in the posterior region. Silver guanine spots scattered in two longitudinal bands dorsally and in lateral surfaces. Venter with a median dusky band that ramifies laterally from posterior tracheal spiracle, guanine silver spots absent. Legs pale yellow-brownish. Tracheal spiracle well-sclerotized. Total length 2.20. Cephalothorax 1.00 long, 0.81 wide, 0.72 high. Abdomen 1.25 long, 1.00 wide, 1.00 high. Sternum 0.52 long, 0.55 wide. Eye diameters and interdistances: AME 0.09. ALE 0.08. PME 0.10. PLE 0.08. AME-AME 0.10, AME-ALE 0.09, PME-PME 0.11, PME-PLE 0.09, ALE-PLE 0.01. Clypeus height 2.11. Chelicerae brownish. Three promarginal and four retromarginal teeth ( Figs. 81 A-C). Ret 1 on the posterior surface ( Fig. 81B ). Leg measurements: I: femur 1.50, patella 0.37, tibia 1.55, metatarsus 1.25, tarsus 0.72, total 5.40; II: 1.30, 0.37, 1.28, 1.00, 0.65, 4.61; III: 0.97, 0.25, 0.72, 0.65, 0.30, 2.90; IV: 1.25, 0.25, 1.05, 0.90, 0.47, 3.92. DTS 0.16. DTE 0.52. Palp as in Figures 82E–H . Conductor lamina apically rounded (
Figs. 82 A – C
,
84 A –B
). Embolus tip bifurcated ( Figs. 82D , 84C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 80.
Glenognatha vivianae
new species
from Brazil (IBSP 147809). A–D, male habitus. A, dorsal. B, lateral. C, ventral. D, frontal. E–H, female habitus. E, dorsal. F, lateral. G, ventral. H, frontal. Scale bars, 200 µm. TS: posterior tracheal spiracle.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Male total length 1.7–2.5 ( N = 10; average 2.1), cephalothorax length 0.9–1.2 ( N = 10; average 1.0), femur I length 1.2–1.5 ( N = 10; average 1.4). Female total length 2.1–3.2 ( N = 10; average 2.5), cephalothorax length 1.0–1.3 ( N = 10; average 1.1), femur I length 1.1–1.5 ( N = 10; average 1.3).

Distribution. Known from the states of São Paulo , Paraná and
Rio Grande
do Sul
in Brazil ( Fig. 135 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 81.
Glenognatha vivianae
new species
from Brazil (Paratype, IBSP 147861). A–C , male left chelicerae. A, anterior. B, posterior. C, mesal. D–F, female left chelicerae. D, anterior. E, posterior. F, mesal. Scale bars, 100 µm. Prt: promarginal tooth. Ret: retromarginal tooth.
